   Assessment and Plan
   The patient is an 83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from
   an OSH for evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large
   pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections
   thought related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoanyeurism hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No hypoglycemia on the scene, and
   no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  EKG w/o evidence of ACS, cardiac markers
   pending.  the patient was noted to be [**Last Name (LF) 12547**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] should consider
   PE.  No right heart strain on EKG.  The patient was noted noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Must also consider more active bleed
   from pseudoaneurism.  Potential for aspiration as precipitating event
   as well
   -- continue intubation for airway protection and ween as tolerated
   -- fentanyl/midaz given active pancratic issues
   -- levophend for pressure support, IVF, ween pressures as tolerated
   -- TTE in am
   -- if have difficulty with oxygenation, will consider CTA for PE
   -- trend hct for e/o of active bleed
   -- CXR
   # Arterial epinephrine:  dopplerable pulse.  Warm and well perfused.
   Continue to monitor.
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections:
   On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling defect, suggestive
   of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS which revealed a
   large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also performed, which
   confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted multiple large abdominal
   fluid collections. He was evaluated by general surgery, who thought his
   abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and associated inflammation
   was relatively immature, and that surgical intervention or drainage at
   this time was not indicated. They recommended that the patient continue
   to be NPO, continue nutrition with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks
   with repeat imaging and clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical
   intervention at that time.
   .
   Patient now with rising WBC, rising lipase, and increasing LUQ pain.
   Repeat imaging reveals interval progression.  Given hemmorhage into
   pseudocyst, may very well be reactive inflammation from hemorrhage.  CT
   did not reveal necrotic component.  Now s/p IR guided embolization of
   GDA pseudoanyeurism bleed.
   .
   - cont vanc/zosyn
   - looks like ID c/s, f/u am recs.  Will hold initiation of meropenem at
   this time.
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - trend hct, if precipitious drop, IR embolization this evening,
   otherwise will reassess stability in am.
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   - cont PO vanc and cont for until has completed other antibiotics then
   for an additional 14d.
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - cont amioderone at 400mg [**Hospital1 **] and clarify plan with primary team
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   - TTE in am
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatining started trending up in
   the last 24hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patinet was pulsesless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds
   - cont mucomyst
   - trend creatinine.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - check Hbg A1c
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Family Contact
   Patient's family contact is the patient's niece [**Name (NI) 12548**] [**Name (NI) 12549**]. Her
   home number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12550**]; work number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12551**]; cell number
   is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12552**]..
   .
   FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO
   .
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   Access: peripheral and PICC
   .
   Code:  Full
   .
   Disposition: ICU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH who was transferred from another hospital for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has been diagnosed with multiple complications, including pancreatic pseudocysts, intra-abdominal fluid collections, atrial fibrillation, hepatic cirrhosis (disputed diagnosis), C. difficile infection, acute renal failure, hyperglycemia, and potential pulmonary embolism.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.5°C, heart rate of 100 bpm, blood pressure of 122/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on supplemental oxygen. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues that require attention. He has a history of pancreatitis with pancreatic pseudocysts and associated fluid collections, which have led to complications such as hemorrhage into a pseudocyst and a gastrointestinal artery pseudoaneurysm. The patient underwent interventional radiology-guided embolization for the pseudoaneurysm.

The patient also has a confirmed diagnosis of C. difficile infection, which started within 48 hours of admission and was treated with oral vancomycin.

There is a dispute regarding the diagnosis of hepatic cirrhosis, with the hepatology team suggesting that it may be secondary to pancreatitis rather than primary liver disease. Hepatitis serologies were unremarkable, and a liver biopsy was recommended

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH who was admitted for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has several medical complications, including pancreatic pseudocysts with intra-abdominal fluid collections, GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, Clostridium difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis.

The patient's current condition includes invasive ventilation, EKG, PICC line, sheath placement, hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated blood glucose levels. His vital signs show a temperature of 38.5°C, heart rate of 100 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 122/50 to 100/120 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on supplemental oxygen.

The patient's lab results indicate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 34.1 K/uL, elevated lipase level of 631 U/L, and elevated lactate level of 2.5 mmol/L. Other lab values such as creatinine, glucose, and liver function tests are also abnormal.

The patient's imaging studies reveal a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections. He underwent an ERCP, which showed a bile duct filling defect suggestive of external compression. A subsequent EUS confirmed the presence of a large pancreatic pseudocyst

Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) who was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of pancreatitis. The patient's course has been complicated by several medical complications, including:

1. Pancreatitis with pancreatic pseudocyst and intra-abdominal fluid collections.
2. Gastroduodenal artery (GDA) pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring interventional radiology (IR) guided embolization.
3. Cardiac arrest of unknown cause, with possible precipitants such as pulmonary embolism (PE), active bleeding from pseudoaneurysm, or aspiration.
4. Clostridium difficile infection (C. diff), which initially presented with increased diarrhea and leukocytosis but improved with treatment.
5. Atrial fibrillation (AF) that was initially treated with amiodarone but may need to be restarted.
6. Acute renal failure (ARF) with rising creatinine levels, possibly related to the recent IR procedure or potential for acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
7. Hyperglycemia due to pancreatic insufficiency or a new diagnosis of diabetes mellitus (DM).
8. Hepatic cirrhosis, although the hepatology team did not confirm it and recommended a liver biopsy.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH who was admitted for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by a GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, which required interventional radiology (IR) guided embolization. 

The patient experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest with unclear precipitants. There was no evidence of hypoglycemia, hypo/hyperkalemia, or acute coronary syndrome (ACS) on the scene. The patient was noted to be hypoxic leading up to the event, and active bleeding from the pseudoaneurysm may also be a consideration. Potential aspiration as a precipitating event was also mentioned.

The patient continues to be intubated for airway protection and weaning as tolerated. He is on fentanyl/midazolam for active pancreatic issues, levophed for pressure support, and IV fluids are being weaned as tolerated. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is planned in the morning, and a lower extremity venous ultrasound (LENS) is recommended for deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism (DVT/PE) rule out. If there is difficulty with oxygenation, a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) for

   83 yom pancreatitis -->  large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, who presented with respiratory failure and experienced a cardiac arrest. The patient has multiple complications including large pancreatic pseudocyst with intra-abdominal fluid collections, gastroduodenal artery pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, hypoxemia, possible pulmonary embolism, hypotension, sepsis, arterial administration of epinephrine, pancreatitis, Staph epidermis bacteremia, pseudocyst with bleeding, Clostridium difficile colitis, possible hepatic cirrhosis, nutritional support, atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure, hyperglycemia, fluid management, and ICU care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. There is a concern for hypoxemia prior to the event, and radiographic evidence of left lower lobe density (atalectasis vs. pneumonia). Monitoring ABG, SaO2, mechanics, and CXR is planned.
2. Cardiac Arrest (PEA): The patient had a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. The cause is unclear, but concerns include hypoxemia (preceding event), aspiration, or hypovolemia (possible further bleed into pseudoaneurysm, third spacing). Monitoring vital signs, checking cardiac echo, and assessing for pulmonary embolism are

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, who presented with a cardiac arrest and subsequent respiratory failure. The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to hypoxemia. The initial assessment indicates possible causes for the cardiac arrest, including hypoxemia, aspiration, or hypovolemia. 

The patient's current condition includes hypotension, attributed to hypovolemia and possible increased blood loss. There is also a concern for sepsis. 

Other ongoing issues include pancreatic pseudocysts with intra-abdominal fluid collections, which may be related to the initial pancreatitis episode. There is also a concern for a gastroduodenal artery pseudoaneurysm and hemorrhage into a pseudocyst. 

Additionally, the patient has developed Staphylococcus epidermidis bacteremia, which is suspected to be line-related. 

The patient's nutritional support consists of total parenteral nutrition (TPN) due to being nil per os (NPO). 

Other medical concerns include atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure, hyperglycemia, and potential hepatic cirrhosis. 

Fluid management is important to maintain central venous pressure (CVP) above 12 and monitor intake and output (I/O). 

In terms of prophylaxis, the patient is receiving systemic anticoagulation for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer prophylaxis with a proton pump inhibitor

   83 yom pancreatitis -->  large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple

   (atalectasis vs. pneumonia).   Plan continue mechanical ventiation,
   monitor ABG, SaO2, mechanics, CXR.
   s/p PEA ARREST -- Unclear precipitant, but concerns include hypoxemia
   (preceeding event), aspiration, or hypovolemia (possible further bleed
   into pseudoaneurysm, 3rd spacing).  Pulmonary embolism possible,
   although no ECG changes (no right heart strain on EKG).   No cooling
   initiated because of active bleeding (and concerns for worsening
   bleeding if cooled).  Neurologically responsive this AM.  Continue to
   monitor VS.  Check cardiac echo, assess for pulmonary embolism (LE

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, currently intubated and mechanically ventilated in the ICU.
- The patient suffered a cardiac arrest and was resuscitated, with unclear precipitants but concerns including hypoxemia, aspiration, or hypovolemia.
- The patient has respiratory failure and remains intubated.
- There are signs of hypotension attributed to hypovolemia, possible increased blood loss, or sepsis.
- The patient has an arterial administration of epinephrine during the code, but no apparent clinical consequences.
- The patient has pancreatitis with pancreatic pseudocysts and intra-abdominal fluid collections.
- There is a suspected line-related Staph epidermis bacteremia.
- The patient has a pseudocyst with interval progression and bleeding.
- The patient is at risk for acute renal failure, anuric renal failure, and hepatomegaly.
- The patient requires nutritional support through total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
- The patient has hyperglycemia, likely related to pancreatitis complications, and requires insulin.
- The patient's fluid status should be maintained with a central venous pressure (CVP) goal of >12.
- The patient has atrial fibrillation (A-FIB) and requires monitoring of heart rate.
- The patient has acute renal failure and requires monitoring of blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine, and urine output. Nephrotoxic medications should be avoided.
- The patient has cirrhosis of the liver, which is a recent development, and a liver biopsy has been recommended.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. Close monitoring of arterial blood gases (ABGs), oxygen saturation (SaO2), and ventilator settings is necessary.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient experienced a cardiac arrest, possibly due to hypoxemia, aspiration, or hypovolemia. Further investigation is needed to determine the exact cause. The patient's code status is full code.
3. Hypotension: The patient has hypotension, likely due to hypovolemia, increased blood loss, or sepsis. Close monitoring of blood pressure and maintaining mean arterial pressure (MAP) >60 mmHg is essential.
4. Pancreatitis complications: The patient has pancreatitis with pseudocysts and intra-abdominal fluid collections. There is a risk of further bleeding into the pseudocyst. Surgical intervention may be required in the future.
5. Infection: The patient has a suspected line-related Staph epidermis bacteremia. Antibiotic therapy should be continued, and source control measures should be taken.
6. Acute renal failure: The patient is at risk

   Assessment and Plan
   The patient is an 83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from
   an OSH for evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large
   pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections
   thought related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoanyeurism hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No hypoglycemia on the scene, and
   no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  EKG w/o evidence of ACS, cardiac markers
   pending.  the patient was noted to be [**Last Name (LF) 12547**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] should consider
   PE.  No right heart strain on EKG.  The patient was noted noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Must also consider more active bleed
   from pseudoaneurism.  Potential for aspiration as precipitating event
   as well.  TTE and LENIS were negative.   Unable to wean pressors, on
   steroid trial.
   -- continue intubation for airway protection and wean as tolerated
   -- fentanyl/midaz given active pancreatic issues
   -- IVF, wean pressors as tolerated
   -- trend hct for e/o of active bleed ([**Hospital1 **])
   # Arterial epinephrine:  dopplerable pulse.  Warm and well perfused.
   Continue to monitor.
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections:
   On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling defect, suggestive
   of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS which revealed a
   large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also performed, which
   confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted multiple large abdominal
   fluid collections. He was evaluated by general surgery, who thought his
   abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and associated inflammation
   was relatively immature, and that surgical intervention or drainage at
   this time was not indicated. They recommended that the patient continue
   to be NPO, continue nutrition with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks
   with repeat imaging and clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical
   intervention at that time..
   Patient now with rising WBC, rising lipase, and increasing LUQ pain.
   Repeat imaging reveals interval progression.  Given hemmorhage into
   pseudocyst, may very well be reactive inflammation from hemorrhage.  CT
   did not reveal necrotic component.  Now s/p IR guided embolization of
   GDA pseudoanyeurism bleed.
   - cont vanc/zosyn
 likely switch to Imipenem/Cilastin
   - looks like ID c/s, f/u am recs
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - trend hct, if precipitious drop, urgent IR embolization, otherwise
   just trend
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   - cont PO vanc and cont for until has completed other antibiotics then
   for an additional 14d.
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - cont amioderone at 400mg [**Hospital1 **] and clarify plan with primary team
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatining started trending up in
   the last 24hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulsesless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.   Worsening today.
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds
   - cont mucomyst
   - trend creatinine.
   - urine lytes with eosinophils
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - check Hbg A1c
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.
   .

   home number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12550**]; work number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12551**]; cell number

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH, who was transferred from an OSH for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has been complicated by GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR-guided embolization. The patient's course is also complicated by acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, C. difficile infection, and alteration in nutrition. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 102.2°F, blood pressure ranging from 110/48 to 122/51 mmHg, heart rate of 90 bpm, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. 

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 36.7 K/uL, elevated levels of lipase at 353 mg/dL, elevated creatinine at 1.4, low albumin at 1.8 g/dL, and elevated lactate at 2.8 mmol/L. The patient's renal function is worsening, and he has evidence of acute kidney injury with a creatinine rise to 1.2 after receiving lasix.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH, admitted for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections related to the pseudocyst. The patient's course is complicated by GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring interventional radiology (IR) guided embolization. The patient experienced two cardiac arrests, one due to a suspected pulmonary embolism and the other likely due to hemorrhage from the pseudoaneurysm. He also developed Clostridium difficile infection, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis (although this diagnosis is uncertain). The patient's condition is complex and requires careful management in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pulmonary embolism (PE): Given the patient's risk factors and recent events, PE should be considered as a potential complication. Further evaluation, such as a computed tomography angiography (CTA), may be necessary if there is difficulty with oxygenation.
2. Hemorrhage from the pseudoaneurysm: The patient has already experienced hemorrhage into the pseudocyst, leading to a cardiac arrest. Close monitoring of hemoglobin (Hct) levels is recommended, and urgent IR embolization should be considered if a precipitous drop in Hct is observed.
3. Clostridium

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia who was transferred from an outside hospital for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by a gastrodudodenal artery pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring interventional radiology-guided embolization.

The patient experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, but the precipitant is unclear. There are no signs of hypoglycemia or electrolyte imbalances. The patient was hypoxic before the event, and potential causes include more active bleeding from the pseudoaneurysm, aspiration, or pulmonary embolism. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and lower extremity Doppler ultrasound were negative.

The patient has a history of pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocysts, intra-abdominal fluid collections, Clostridium difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. His vital signs include a temperature of 102.2°F, blood pressure of 110/48 mmHg, heart rate of 90 bpm, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96% on 50% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 36.7 K/uL, elevated lipase levels, and increasing left upper quadrant pain. His blood glucose levels are elevated at 353 mg/dL. He has a creatinine level of 2.7 mg/dL and liver enzymes showing mild elevation. Other labs indicate possible ongoing inflammation or infection.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pulmonary embolism (PE) - The patient's hypoxia and PEA arrest may raise suspicion for PE. A computed tomography angiography (CTA) for PE could be considered if there is difficulty with oxygenation.
2. Active bleeding - The patient's hypotension and drop in hemoglobin could indicate ongoing internal bleeding, possibly from the gastrodudodenal artery pseudoaneurysm or other sources.
3. Aspiration - Given the patient's intubation status and risk factors, aspiration pneumonia is a concern.
4. Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) - The patient has a history of CDI, and appropriate antibiotics should be continued.
5. Acute renal failure - The patient's rising creatinine levels suggest worsening renal function. Nephrotoxic medications should be avoided, and fluid management should be optimized.
6. Hyperglycemia - The patient's elevated blood glucose levels require careful monitoring and management.
7. Hepatic cirrhosis - Although the patient's hepatic cirrhosis

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis and subsequent development of a pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections. The patient experienced a cardiac arrest and was resuscitated, but unfortunately, remains in critical condition.

The patient's current medical conditions include respiratory failure, hypoxemia, and possible aspiration pneumonia. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. There is evidence of lower lobe density on radiographic imaging, which could be due to atelectasis or pneumonia.

The patient also had a cardiac arrest with an unclear precipitant, but concerns include hypoxemia (preceeding event), aspiration, or hypovolemia (possible further bleed into pseudoaneurysm, third spacing). Pulmonary embolism is a possibility, although no ECG changes (no right heart strain on EKG), left lower extremity non-invasive ventilation without DVT, and cardiac echo without evidence for right ventricular strain.

The patient has hypotension attributed to sepsis, pancreatitis, and possible hypovolemia, and blood loss. The patient's blood pressure is being monitored, and the plan is to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 60 mmHg.

Anemia is present and attributed to bleeding of pseudoaneurysm into pseudocyst. The patient's arterial administration of epinephrine occurred during the code, but there were no apparent

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male who was admitted with acute pancreatitis and developed a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections. The patient then experienced a gastroduodenal artery pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst and subsequently had a cardiac arrest with pulseless electrical activity (PEA). The patient has been intubated and is on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure.

The patient has several medical complications that need to be addressed. Firstly, there is hypoxemia prior to the cardiac arrest, and the plan is to continue mechanical ventilation and monitor ABG, SaO2, mechanics, and CXR. Secondly, the patient had a PEA arrest with unclear precipitants, but concerns include hypoxemia, aspiration, or hypovolemia due to possible further bleeding into the pseudoaneurysm or third spacing. Pulmonary embolism is also a possibility, although no ECG changes were observed. LE NIVS without DVT and cardiac echo without evidence for RV strain were performed. No cooling was initiated due to active bleeding concerns. Thirdly, the patient is hypotensive, attributed to sepsis, pancreatitis, and possible hypovolemia, as well as blood loss. Monitoring of BP and maintaining MAP > 60 mmHg is recommended.

Additionally, the patient is anemic due to bleeding of the pseudoaneurysm into the pseud

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) who was transferred from another hospital for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has been diagnosed with multiple medical complications including acute renal failure, pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocysts, intra-abdominal fluid collections, Clostridium difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis. The patient experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, which was likely caused by hemorrhage into a pseudocyst or a more active bleed from a pseudoaneurysm. He underwent interventional radiology (IR) guided embolization of the gastrointestinal duct artery (GDA) pseudoaneurysm bleed. The patient's condition is complicated by several factors including kidney injury, infection, fluid imbalance, and multiorgan dysfunction.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, indicating worsening kidney function. This could be due to intrinsic renal injury or prerenal causes such as hypovolemia or cardiogenic shock.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's lipase levels are elevated, suggesting ongoing inflammation of the pancreas. There is a risk of further pancreatic necrosis, pseudocyst formation, and complications related to fluid collections.
3. Intra-abdominal Fluid Collections: The presence of multiple fluid collections around the pancreas may

The patient experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest with an unclear precipitant, and further evaluation is pending. The patient is currently intubated for airway protection and weaning of pressors as tolerated. The patient's Hct continues to drop, and he will undergo IR-guided embolization of the GDA pseudoaneurysm today.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated WBC count, lipase levels, and creatinine, indicating ongoing inflammation and renal dysfunction. The patient's electrolytes are relatively stable, with the exception of slightly elevated potassium.

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a chief complaint of fever. The patient's medical history includes acute pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocyst, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), acute renal failure (acute renal failure, ARF), Clostridium difficile infection, alteration in nutrition, aneurysm, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and other conditions.

The patient's current vital signs are as follows: temperature of 101.1 degrees Fahrenheit, heart rate of 106 beats per minute, blood pressure of 114/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%.

The patient is currently receiving midazolam, phenylephrine, vasopressin, fentanyl, and norepinephrine infusions. They are also receiving pantoprazole and other medications.

The patient's lab results show elevated levels of white blood cells (WBC), potassium (K+), glucose, and lactate. The creatinine level is steadily worsening, with a FeNa of 1.44% and a FeUrea of 11%. The patient's hemoglobin concentration (Hct) has been trending downward, and they received a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells (pRBC).

The patient's fluid balance over the past 24 hours shows a total input of 3,441 mL and a total output of 1,059 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 2,382 mL.

The patient's respiratory support includes being on a ventilator in the assist-control mode with a tidal volume (Vt) set at 500 mL, respiratory rate (RR) set at 24 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. The patient's blood gases (ABG) show a pH of 7.32, PaCO2 of 36 mmHg, PaO2 of 244 mmHg, and a respiratory system compliance of 29.4 cmH2O/mL.

The patient's physical examination findings are incomplete due to their inability to assess certain parameters such as peripheral pulses, skin condition, neurologic response, and tone.

The patient's assessment and plan include acute pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocyst, acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, Clostridium difficile infection, alteration in nutrition, aneurysm, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and other conditions.

   The patient is an 83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from
   an OSH for evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large
   pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections
   thought related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No hypoglycemia on the scene, and
   no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  EKG w/o evidence of ACS, cardiac markers
   pending.  the patient was noted to be tachypneic, so should consider
   PE.  No right heart strain on EKG.  The patient was noted noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Must also consider more active bleed
   from pseudoaneurysm.  Potential for aspiration as precipitating event
   as well.  TTE and LENIS were negative.   Unable to wean pressors, on
   steroid v placebo trial.
   -- continue intubation for airway protection and wean as tolerated
   -- fentanyl/midaz given active pancreatic issues
   -- IVF, wean pressors as tolerated
   -- trend hct for e/o of active bleed ([**Hospital1 **])
   -- consider CTA for eval for PE, especially if patient is to start CRRT
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatining started trending up in
   the last 48hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulsesless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%. Worsening today,
   uptrending by 0.3 daily.
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds
 d/c
d vancomycin, checking levels, redose
   when < 15
   - trend creatinine.
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT; renal c/s today
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections:
   On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling defect, suggestive
   of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS which revealed a
   large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also performed, which
   confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted multiple large abdominal
   fluid collections. He was evaluated by general surgery, who thought his
   abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and associated inflammation
   was relatively immature, and that surgical intervention or drainage at
   this time was not indicated. They recommended that the patient continue
   to be NPO, continue nutrition with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks
   with repeat imaging and clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical
   intervention at that time..
   Patient now with rising WBC, rising lipase, and increasing LUQ pain.
   Repeat imaging reveals interval progression.  Given hemorrhage into

   did not reveal necrotic component.
   - continue meropenem
   - ID recs
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - Hct continues to drop; patient will go for IR-guided embolization of
   GDA pseudoaneurysm today
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   - cont vanc enemas and cont for until has completed other antibiotics
   then for an additional 14d.
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - cont amiodarone at 400mg [**Hospital1 **] and clarify plan with primary team
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.
   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH and pancreatitis. He was admitted to the ICU for evaluation and treatment of pancreatitis. The patient's course has been complicated by several medical complications including GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, acute renal failure, Clostridium difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. GDA Pseudoaneurysm Hemorrhage: The patient experienced hemorrhage into a pseudocyst due to a GDA pseudoaneurysm. This required immediate intervention with interventional radiology (IR)-guided embolization.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have been steadily worsening, indicating acute renal failure. This may be due to various factors such as ATN, intrarenal process, or potential contrast-induced nephropathy from the IR procedure.

3. Clostridium difficile infection: The patient developed increased diarrhea and marked leukocytosis after admission, and tested positive for C. diff. He was started on Flagyl and later transitioned to PO vancomycin.

4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and initially treated with diltiazem and amiodarone. However, his PICC line may have been triggering the atrial fibrillation

   Assessment and Plan
   83 yom pancreatitis -->  large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple
   intra-abdominal fluid collections (?related to pseudocyst) -->
   gastroduodenal artery pseudoanyeurism hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, now
   s/p cardiac arrest (?PEA).  Overall, worsening clinical status.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- intubated in context of cardiac arrest.
   Hypoxemia prior to event.  Radiographic evidence for LLL density
   (atalectasis vs. pneumonia).   Plan continue mechanical ventiation,
   monitor ABG, SaO2, mechanics, CXR.
   s/p PEA ARREST -- Unclear precipitant, but concerns include hypoxemia
   (preceeding event), aspiration, or hypovolemia (possible further bleed
   into pseudoaneurysm, 3rd spacing).  Pulmonary embolism possible,
   although no ECG changes (no right heart strain on EKG), LE NIVS without
   DVT and cardiac echo without evidence for RV strain.   No cooling
   initiated because of active bleeding (and concerns for worsening
   bleeding if cooled).  Neurologically responsive initially, now on
   sedation.  Continue to monitor VS.
   HYPOTENSION -- attributed to sepsis, pancreatitis, and possible
   hypovolemia, and blood loss (less).  Concern for possible pulmonary
   embolism.  Monitor BP, maintain MAP > 60 mmHg.  Plan to proceed with CT
   angio
 if clot identified, then would place IVC filter while remains
   at risk for bleeding.
   GDA ANERYSM
 will require IR-guided embolization when stable.  Hold
   anticoagulation.  If PE identified, will need IVC filter pending final
   intervention for aneurysm.
   ANEMIA -- attributed to bleeding of pseudoaneurysm into pseudocyst,
   phlebotomy.  Continues to require transfusion.
   PANCREATITIS -- c/b  Pancreatic Pseudocysts, multiple intra-abdominal
   fluid Collections.   General Surgery recommended that the patient
   continue to be NPO, continue nutrition with TPN, and then follow-up in
   [**5-6**] weeks with repeat imaging and clinic follow-up for consideration of
   surgical intervention at that time.
   STAPH EPI BACTERIMIA -- suspect line-related.  Continue Vanco.
   PSEUDOCYST -- Rising WBC, rising lipase, and increasing LUQ pain.
   Repeat imaging reveals interval progression, with bleeding.   Continue
   vanc/zosyn.  ID consult in progress.
   RASH -- diffuse, blanching erythema.  Suspect drug-related (probable
   antimicrobial).
   C. DIFF COLITIS --  Continue PO vanc for an additional 14 days.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT -- TPN.
   A-FIB -- new recent problem, plan monitor HR.
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE -- anuric renal failure, in context of
   arrest/code.  Probable ATN.  Monitor BUN, creatinine, uo.  Avoid
   nephrotoxic meds, provide.mucomyst.  At risk for dye-induced renal
   injury required for CT angio and IR-directed embolization.
   HYPERGLYCEMIA -- Likely related to pancreatitis complications.
   Continue insulin.
   FLUIDS -- maintain CVP >12.   Monitor I/O.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis who has developed multiple complications. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Pneumonia: The patient has an increased risk of developing pneumonia due to being intubated and immobile.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): This is a specific type of pneumonia that occurs in patients who are on mechanical ventilation for more than 48 hours.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient has lower extremity edema and is at risk for developing blood clots in the deep veins, which can potentially travel to the lungs and cause a pulmonary embolism.
4. Sepsis: The patient has an infection with Staphylococcus epidermidis bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis, especially if it is a line-related infection.
5. Acute renal failure: The patient is anuric and has evidence of acute renal failure, which could be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, likely related to complications of pancreatitis.
7. Clostridium difficile colitis: The patient has been treated with vancomycin for suspected Staphylococcus epidermidis bacteremia and

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, currently admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure. He has been intubated and mechanically ventilated. The patient remains on vasopressors and is tolerating slowly weaning. He has anuric renal failure and received a unit of packed red blood cells for progressive anemia.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.4°C (101.1°F), heart rate of 110 bpm, blood pressure of 118/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is in atrial fibrillation.

Physical examination reveals right lower extremity edema, left lower extremity edema, warm and dry skin, and diffuse erythematous blanching rash over the trunk. Neurologically, the patient is sedated but purposeful and responsive to verbal stimuli.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 25.3 K/uL, elevated glucose level of 353 mg/dL, elevated creatinine level of 2.7 mg/dL, and elevated lactate level of 1.8 mmol/L.

The patient's medical history includes pancreatitis with the formation of a pancreatic pseudocyst, multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections, and a gastroduodenal artery pseudoaneurysm. The patient experienced a cardiac arrest, likely due

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, who has developed multiple complications including respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, hypotension, gastrointestinal bleeding, renal failure, and sepsis. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, receiving vasopressor support and has anuria. 

The patient's current condition is critical, and several potential medical complications can arise. These include worsening respiratory failure, further deterioration of renal function, development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and potential pulmonary embolism. The patient also has a pseudocyst with a suspected bleeding pseudoaneurysm that requires intervention. 

Further management will involve monitoring vital signs, ABG results, and chest X-ray for respiratory status, as well as maintaining hemodynamic stability with appropriate vasopressor support. Renal function should be closely monitored, and if there is no improvement, renal replacement therapy may be necessary. 

Additionally, the patient's coagulation status should be evaluated, and a CT angiogram may be performed to assess for pulmonary embolism. If present, an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter may be considered. The bleeding pseudoaneurysm will require interventional radiology (IR)-guided embolization. 

Nutritional support through total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is recommended, and glycemic control should be maintained with insulin. Fluid balance should be closely monitored to maintain adequate CVP levels.

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) who was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has developed several complications during his hospital stay, including a gastrointestinal (GI) bleed from a pseudoaneurysm, acute renal failure (ARF), Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to airway protection and respiratory distress. He has multiple IV lines, including an arterial line and PICC line. The patient's condition is unstable, and he requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pseudoaneurysm: The patient has a history of GI bleed due to a pseudoaneurysm, which is a ruptured blood vessel within a pseudocyst. This complication can lead to significant blood loss and hemorrhagic shock. Close monitoring of vital signs and continuous blood pressure measurement is essential to detect any signs of hemodynamic instability.

2. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine levels have been increasing, indicating worsening kidney function. ARF can lead to fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and the need for renal replacement therapy (RRT). Frequent monitoring of renal function markers and daily weight measurements should be performed.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from an OSH for
   evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large pancreatic
   pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections thought
   related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No hypoglycemia on the scene, and
   no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  EKG w/o evidence of ACS, cardiac markers
   pending.  the patient was noted to be tachypneic, so should consider
   PE.  No right heart strain on EKG.  The patient was noted noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Must also consider more active bleed
   from pseudoaneurysm.  Potential for aspiration as precipitating event
   as well.  TTE and LENIS were negative.   Unable to wean pressors, on
   steroid v placebo trial.  Still worried about PE as causal
   -- continue intubation for airway protection and wean as tolerated
   -- fentanyl/midaz given active pancreatic issues
   -- IVF, wean pressors as tolerated
   -- trend hct for e/o of active bleed ([**Hospital1 **])
   -- consider CTA for eval for PE, especially if patient is to start CRRT
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatining started trending up in
   the last 48hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulsesless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%. Worsening today,
   uptrending by 0.3 daily.
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds
 d/c
d vancomycin, checking levels, redose
   when < 15
   - trend creatinine.
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT; renal c/s today
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections:
   On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling defect, suggestive
   of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS which revealed a
   large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also performed, which
   confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted multiple large abdominal
   fluid collections. He was evaluated by general surgery, who thought his
   abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and associated inflammation
   was relatively immature, and that surgical intervention or drainage at
   this time was not indicated. They recommended that the patient continue
   to be NPO, continue nutrition with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks
   with repeat imaging and clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical
   intervention at that time..
   Patient now with rising WBC, rising lipase, and increasing LUQ pain.
   Repeat imaging reveals interval progression.  Given hemorrhage into
   pseudocyst, may very well be reactive inflammation from hemorrhage.  CT
   did not reveal necrotic component.
   - continue meropenem
   - ID recs
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - Hct continues to drop; patient will go for IR-guided embolization of
   GDA pseudoaneurysm today
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   - cont vanc enemas and cont for until has completed other antibiotics
   then for an additional 14d.
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - cont amiodarone at 400mg [**Hospital1 **] and clarify plan with primary team
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.
   .
   # Family Contact
   Patient's family contact is the patient's niece [**Name (NI) 12548**] [**Name (NI) 12549**]. Her
   home number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12550**]; work number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12551**]; cell number
   is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12552**]..
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient has risk factors for PE, such as immobilization and tachypnea. A CT angiogram (CTA) was performed, which revealed no central or segmental pulmonary embolism, but could not entirely exclude small subsegmental pulmonary embolisms. Further evaluation may be needed if the patient's condition worsens.

2. Renal failure: The patient has a history of acute renal failure during his admission at the OSH, with a creatinine level of 1.9. His creatinine has been trending up in the last 48 hours. He received one dose of lasix on the floor, and his Cr rose to 1.2. Given the potential for ATN due to pulsesless state for 10 minutes, avoiding nephrotoxic medications and considering continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) may be necessary.

3. Pancreatitis and pancreatic pseudocysts: The patient has a history of pancreatitis with large pancreatic pseudocysts and associated inflammation. There is a concern for complications such as hemorrhage into the pseudocyst, which may require interventional radiology (IR)-guided embolization.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis who is currently in the ICU. He remains intubated and mechanically ventilated. The patient experienced a cardiac arrest and was resuscitated, but there is uncertainty about the underlying cause. His clinical status has been worsening, with respiratory failure, hypoxemia, and signs of sepsis. There are also concerns about possible pulmonary embolism, hypovolemia, and bleeding from a gastroduodenal artery pseudoaneurysm. The patient has anemia, acute renal failure, hyperglycemia, and other complications related to pancreatitis and critical illness.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory function is compromised due to mechanical ventilation and the presence of a pseudocyst in the pancreas.
2. Cardiac Arrest: The patient experienced a cardiac arrest, possibly related to hypoxemia, aspiration, or hypovolemia.
3. Sepsis: The patient shows signs of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and increased mortality.
4. Pulmonary Embolism: There is a concern for pulmonary embolism due to the patient's immobilization and risk factors.
5. Hypovolemia: The patient may have hypovolemia due to bleeding from the pseudoaneurysm, further bleeding into the pseudocyst, and third spacing of fluids.
6. Acute Renal Failure

   83 yom pancreatitis -->  large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple

   gastroduodenal artery pseudoanyeurism hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, now
   s/p cardiac arrest (?PEA).  Overall, worsening clinical status.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- intubated in context of cardiac arrest.
   Hypoxemia prior to event.  Radiographic evidence for LLL density
   (atalectasis vs. pneumonia).   Plan continue mechanical ventiation,
   monitor ABG, SaO2, mechanics, CXR.
   s/p PEA ARREST -- Unclear precipitant, but concerns include hypoxemia
   (preceeding event), aspiration, or hypovolemia (possible further bleed
   into pseudoaneurysm, 3rd spacing).  Pulmonary embolism possible,
   although no ECG changes (no right heart strain on EKG), LE NIVS without
   DVT and cardiac echo without evidence for RV strain.   No cooling
   initiated because of active bleeding (and concerns for worsening
   bleeding if cooled).  Neurologically responsive initially, now on
   sedation.  Continue to monitor VS.
   HYPOTENSION -- attributed to sepsis, pancreatitis, and possible
   hypovolemia, and blood loss (less).  Concern for possible pulmonary
   embolism.  Monitor BP, maintain MAP > 60 mmHg.  Plan to proceed with CT

 if clot identified, then would place IVC filter while remains
   at risk for bleeding.
   GDA ANERYSM
 will require IR-guided embolization when stable.  Hold
   anticoagulation.  If PE identified, will need IVC filter pending final
   intervention for aneurysm.

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, who has developed a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections. The patient also has a gastroduodenal artery pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, resulting in cardiac arrest with return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). 

The patient's current condition is characterized by respiratory failure, intubated due to cardiac arrest, hypoxemia prior to the event, and radiographic evidence for left lower lobe density (atalectasis vs. pneumonia). The plan is to continue mechanical ventilation, monitor ABG, SaO2, mechanics, and CXR.

The patient has had a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, with unclear precipitants. Possible concerns include hypoxemia (preceeding event), aspiration, or hypovolemia (possible further bleed into pseudoaneurysm, third spacing). Pulmonary embolism is also a concern, although no ECG changes (no right heart strain on EKG), and left lower extremity non-invasive venous stasis without deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and cardiac echo without evidence for right ventricular strain. No cooling was initiated because of active bleeding (and concerns for worsening bleeding if cooled). The patient is still sedated and neurologically responsive initially.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from an OSH for
   evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large pancreatic
   pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections thought
   related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatining started trending up in
   the last 48hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulseless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%. Worsening today,
   uptrending by 0.3 daily.
   - trial bolus of lasix to see if UOP improves; if he fails, start CVVH
   per Renal
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds; d/ced vancomycin
   - trend creatinine.
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT
   - f/u renal recs re: when to start CRRT
   .
   # Unresponsiveness S/p PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No
   hypoglycemia on the scene, and no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  EKG w/o
   evidence of ACS, cardiac markers pending.  the patient was noted to be
   tachypneic, so should consider PE.  No right heart strain on EKG.  The
   patient was noted noted to be hypoxic leading up to the event.  Must
   also consider more active bleed from pseudoaneurysm.  Potential for
   aspiration as precipitating event as well.  TTE, LENIs, CTA neg.
   - continue intubation for airway protection and wean as tolerated
   - avoiding BZDs today, continue fentanyl
   - IVF, wean pressors as tolerated
   - trend Hct for e/o of active bleed ([**Hospital1 **])
   .
   # AMS
 Still unresponsive after discontinuation of midazolam for
   sedation.  Rhythmic motion of R leg concerning for seizure. Worried
   that bzd were masking seizure
   - EEG to r/o epileptiform activity
   - hold on head imaging for now
   - continue to reassess mental status s/p withdrawal of midazolam this
   AM
   .
   # aspiration pneumonia
   - D6/8 of antibiotics; no source grown from sputum cx
   - switching from meropenem to zosyn given ID recs
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections:
   On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling defect, suggestive
   of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS which revealed a
   large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also performed, which
   confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted multiple large abdominal
   fluid collections. He was evaluated by general surgery, who thought his
   abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and associated inflammation
   was relatively immature, and that surgical intervention or drainage at
   this time was not indicated. They recommended that the patient continue
   to be NPO, continue nutrition with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks
   with repeat imaging and clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical
   intervention at that time..
   Patient now with rising WBC, rising lipase, and increasing LUQ pain.
   Repeat imaging reveals interval progression.  Given hemorrhage into
   pseudocyst, may very well be reactive inflammation from hemorrhage.  CT
   did not reveal necrotic component.
   - ID recs
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - Hct continues to drop; patient will go for IR-guided embolization of
   GDA pseudoaneurysm today
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   Now with worsening abdominal distention, although this could be from
   massive fluid overload.
   - cont vanc enemas and cont for until has completed other antibiotics
   then for an additional 14d
   - add IV flagyl per ID recs
   - KUB: limited evaluation
   - transduce bladder pressure
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - amiodarone redosed to gtt given inability to administer PO meds
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.
   .
   # Family Contact
   Patient's family contact is the patient's niece [**Name (NI) 12548**] [**Name (NI) 12549**]. Her
   home number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12550**]; work number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12551**]; cell number
   is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12552**]..
   .

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH, admitted to the ICU for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections. The patient's course is complicated by GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR-guided embolization. The patient experienced a pulseless event (PEA arrest) and is currently unresponsive. He also has acute renal failure, AMS (altered mental status), aspiration pneumonia, Clostridium difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are rising, indicating worsening renal function. The cause of acute renal failure could be related to the pulseless event or ongoing intra-abdominal processes.

2. Unresponsiveness/PEA Arrest: The patient experienced a pulseless event, resulting in prolonged hypoxia and possible brain injury. Further investigation is needed to determine the precipitant of the event and to rule out potential causes such as cardiac issues, pulmonary embolism, or massive bleeding from the pseudoaneurysm.

3. AMS: The patient remains unresponsive after discontinuation of midazolam sedation. Rhythmic motion of the right leg suggests possible seizure activity. An EEG should be performed to rule out epileptiform activity.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from an OSH for
   evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large pancreatic
   pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections thought
   related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatining started trending up in
   the last 48hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulseless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%. Worsening today,
   uptrending by 0.3 daily.
   - start CVVH
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds; d/ced vancomycin
   - trend creatinine.
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT
   - f/u renal recs re: when to start CRRT
   .
   # PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No hypoglycemia on the scene, and
   no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  EKG w/o evidence of ACS, cardiac markers
   pending.  the patient was noted to be tachypneic, so should consider
   PE.  No right heart strain on EKG.  The patient was noted noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Must also consider more active bleed
   from pseudoaneurysm.  Potential for aspiration as precipitating event
   as well.  TTE, LENIs, CTA neg.
   - continue intubation for airway protection and wean as tolerated
   - avoiding BZDs today, continue fentanyl
   - IVF, wean pressors as tolerated
   - trend Hct for e/o of active bleed ([**Hospital1 **])
   .
   # AMS
 Still unresponsive after discontinuation of midazolam for
   sedation.  Rhythmic motion of R leg concerning for seizure.
   - EEG to r/o epileptiform activity
   - hold on head imaging for now
   - continue to reassess mental status s/p withdrawal of midazolam this
   AM
   .
   # aspiration pneumonia
   - D6/8 of antibiotics; no source grown from sputum cx
   - switching from meropenem to zosyn given ID recs
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections:
   On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling defect, suggestive
   of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS which revealed a
   large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also performed, which
   confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted multiple large abdominal
   fluid collections. He was evaluated by general surgery, who thought his
   abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and associated inflammation
   was relatively immature, and that surgical intervention or drainage at
   this time was not indicated. They recommended that the patient continue
   to be NPO, continue nutrition with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks
   with repeat imaging and clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical
   intervention at that time..
   Patient now with rising WBC, rising lipase, and increasing LUQ pain.
   Repeat imaging reveals interval progression.  Given hemorrhage into
   pseudocyst, may very well be reactive inflammation from hemorrhage.  CT
   did not reveal necrotic component.
   - Zosyn
   - ID recs
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - Hct continues to drop; patient will go for IR-guided embolization of
   GDA pseudoaneurysm today
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   - cont vanc enemas and cont for until has completed other antibiotics
   then for an additional 14d
   - add IV flagyl per ID recs
   - KUB today to assess for megacolon
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - amiodarone redosed to gtt given inability to administer PO meds
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.
   .

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) who was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has been complicated by several medical conditions during his hospital stay. 

1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have been trending up, indicating worsening renal function. He had a previous episode of acute renal failure during his admission at another hospital, and it is suspected that he may develop acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to his recent pulseless event. The plan is to start continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) and avoid nephrotoxic medications.

2. Pulseless Event (PEA arrest): The patient experienced a pulseless event, and the cause is unclear. No hypoglycemia or evidence of acute coronary syndrome was found. The patient was hypoxic leading up to the event, and a potential active bleed from the pseudoaneurysm should be considered. An echocardiogram, CT angiography, and laboratory tests are pending to further evaluate the situation.

3. Alterative Mental Status (AMS): The patient remains unresponsive after discontinuing midazolam, a sedative medication. Rhythmic motion of the right leg suggests the possibility of a seizure, so an electroencephalogram (EEG) will be performed to rule out epileptiform activity. 

4. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient developed aspiration pneumonia

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for evaluation of acute pancreatitis. The patient's course has been complicated by several medical complications, including acute renal failure, pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, altered mental status (AMS), aspiration pneumonia, Clostridium difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis.

The patient underwent an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) that revealed a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections. A computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the presence of a large pseudocyst and identified a gastrodudodenal artery (GDA) pseudoaneurysm, which was successfully treated with interventional radiology (IR)-guided embolization.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lipase levels, and lactate levels, indicating ongoing inflammation and potential infection. His renal function has deteriorated, with increasing creatinine levels and oliguria. The patient also has electrolyte imbalances, including hypokalemia and hyponatremia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure ranging from 110 to 120 mmHg and a heart rate between 76 and 107 beats per minute. His respiratory
