   Assessment and Plan
   83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from an OSH for
   evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large pancreatic
   pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections thought
   related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatining started trending up in
   the last 48hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulseless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%. Worsening today,
   uptrending by 0.3 daily.
   - start CVVH
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds; d/ced vancomycin
   - trend creatinine.
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT
   - f/u renal recs re: when to start CRRT
   .
   # PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No hypoglycemia on the scene, and
   no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  EKG w/o evidence of ACS, cardiac markers
   pending.  the patient was noted to be tachypneic, so should consider
   PE.  No right heart strain on EKG.  The patient was noted noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Must also consider more active bleed
   from pseudoaneurysm.  Potential for aspiration as precipitating event
   as well.  TTE, LENIs, CTA neg.
   - continue intubation for airway protection and wean as tolerated
   - avoiding BZDs today, continue fentanyl
   - IVF, wean pressors as tolerated
   - trend Hct for e/o of active bleed ([**Hospital1 **])
   .
   # AMS
 Still unresponsive after discontinuation of midazolam for
   sedation.  Rhythmic motion of R leg concerning for seizure.
   - EEG to r/o epileptiform activity
   - hold on head imaging for now
   - continue to reassess mental status s/p withdrawal of midazolam this
   AM
   .
   # aspiration pneumonia
   - D6/8 of antibiotics; no source grown from sputum cx
   - switching from meropenem to zosyn given ID recs
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections:
   On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling defect, suggestive
   of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS which revealed a
   large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also performed, which
   confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted multiple large abdominal
   fluid collections. He was evaluated by general surgery, who thought his
   abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and associated inflammation
   was relatively immature, and that surgical intervention or drainage at
   this time was not indicated. They recommended that the patient continue
   to be NPO, continue nutrition with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks
   with repeat imaging and clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical
   intervention at that time..
   Patient now with rising WBC, rising lipase, and increasing LUQ pain.
   Repeat imaging reveals interval progression.  Given hemorrhage into
   pseudocyst, may very well be reactive inflammation from hemorrhage.  CT
   did not reveal necrotic component.
   - Zosyn
   - ID recs
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - Hct continues to drop; patient will go for IR-guided embolization of
   GDA pseudoaneurysm today
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   - cont vanc enemas and cont for until has completed other antibiotics
   then for an additional 14d
   - add IV flagyl per ID recs
   - KUB: limited evaluation
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - amiodarone redosed to gtt given inability to administer PO meds
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.
   .

He has a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections. His course is complicated by a gastroduodenal artery (GDA) pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, which required interventional radiology (IR) guided embolization. The patient also has acute renal failure, pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, Clostridium difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis. The patient's family contact is his niece, who can be reached at [**Name (NI) 12548**] [**Name (NI) 12549**].

The patient's urine electrolytes are consistent with an intrarenal process, and he is showing signs of worsening renal function.

Based on the provided progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient. These include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. Monitoring ABG, SaO2, and mechanics is necessary.

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is attributed to sepsis, pancreatitis, and possible hypovolemia. It is important to monitor the patient's blood pressure and maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg.

3. GDA aneurysm: The patient experienced a gastroduodenal artery pseudoaneurysm, which has been successfully embolized. Anticoagulation should be held, and further imaging may be required.

4. Rhythmic movement of right leg: The patient displays rhythmic movement of the right leg, which could be a concern for focal seizure. An EEG should be performed to assess this further, and head imaging may be considered.

5. Anemia: The patient is anemic, likely due to bleeding from the pseudoaneurysm into the pseudocyst and phlebotomy. Continued transfusion support may be necessary.

6. Pancreatitis: The patient has pancreatitis with associated complications such as pancreatic pseudocysts and multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections. General surgery recommends continued nasogastric tube placement, total parenteral nutrition (TPN), and follow-up imaging

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis and multiple complications. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. The patient has been through cardiac arrest and was resuscitated.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and there is evidence of hypoxemia prior to the cardiac arrest. Continued monitoring and support with mechanical ventilation are necessary.
2. Pseudocyst with bleeding: The patient has a large pancreatic pseudocyst with intra-abdominal fluid collections, which may lead to further bleeding. Close monitoring and consideration of surgical intervention may be required.
3. Hypotension: The patient is experiencing hypotension attributed to sepsis, pancreatitis, and possible hypovolemia. Close monitoring of blood pressure and maintaining a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg is essential.
4. GDA aneurysm: The patient had a gastroduodenal artery pseudoaneurysm, which was successfully embolized. Anticoagulation should be avoided, and the patient's condition should be closely monitored.
5. Rhythmic movement of right leg: The patient exhibits rhythmic movement of the right leg, which may indicate a focal seizure. An electroencephalogram (EEG) should be performed to assess the brain activity, and consideration for head imaging is necessary.
6. Anemia: The patient has anemia likely due to bleeding of the pseudoaneurysm into the pseudocyst and phlebotomy. Transfusion support may be needed.
7. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis requires ongoing management with nutritional support through total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and close monitoring. Surgical intervention may be necessary in the future.
8. Staph epidermidis bacteremia: The patient is suspected to have Staph epidermidis bacteremia, possibly related to a central line. Vancomycin therapy has been initiated.
9. Pseudocyst progression: The patient's pseudocyst is worsening, with increasing white blood cell count, rising lipase levels, and increasing left upper quadrant pain. Repeat imaging reveals interval progression with bleeding. Antibiotic therapy and further evaluation by an infectious disease consultant are necessary.
10. Rash: The patient has developed a diffuse, blanching erythema, which is suspected to be drug-related, most likely an antimicrobial agent. The medication causing the rash should be discontinued if possible.
11. Clostridium difficile colitis: The patient may have developed Clostridium difficile colitis, and treatment with oral vancomycin for an additional 14 days is recommended. Monitoring for toxic megacolon and abdominal imaging may be required.
12. Acute renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, possibly due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Close monitoring

   CT ABDOMEN
   1. Extensive fluid collections identified in the abdomen and pelvis,
   most of
   which are stable in size. Percutaneous drains remain in situ within one
   of
   these along the right. A new fluid collection is seen adjacent to the
   pancreatic tail extending along small bowel loops to the left abdominal
   flank.
   2. New areas of consolidation and ground-glass opacity are identified
   in the
   right middle lobe and right lower lobe consistent with pneumonia or
   aspiration.
   Assessment and Plan
   83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from an OSH for
   evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large pancreatic
   pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections thought
   related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatinine started trending up in
   the last 48hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulseless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%.  Worsening today,
   uptrending by 0.3 daily.
   - UOP improved today on lasix, but Cr still rising, worsening
   hyponatremia
   - monitor lytes [**Hospital1 **]; trend Cr
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT
 reconfirm
   - f/u renal recs re: when to start CRRT (goals of care)
   - check pm lytes
   .
   # Unresponsiveness S/p PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No
   hypoglycemia on the scene, and no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  Cardiac
   enzymes and CTA chest were negative.  The patient was noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Still unresponsive after
   discontinuation of midazolam for sedation.  DDx includes sedation
   (impaired renal clearance), uremia, structural defect (i.e. stroke),
   seizure, metabolic (i.e. hyponatremia).
   - f/u EEG resuls to r/o epileptiform activity
   - hold on head imaging for now
   - continue to reassess mental status s/p withdrawal of midazolam this
   AM
   .
   # aspiration +/- PNA
 as seen on CT chest
   - continue intubation and wean as tolerated
   - currently on Zosyn
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections: On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling
   defect, suggestive of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS
   which revealed a large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also
   performed, which confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted
   multiple large abdominal fluid collections. He was evaluated by general
   surgery, who thought his abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and
   associated inflammation was relatively immature, and that surgical
   intervention or drainage at this time was not indicated. They
   recommended that the patient continue to be NPO, continue nutrition
   with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks with repeat imaging and
   clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical intervention at that
   time.  Now s/p IR-guided embolization of GDA pseudoaneurysm, which
   appeared to have hemorrhaged into a pseudocyst.
    - was on meropenem; switched to Zosyn per ID recs as they felt that it
   could explain his abdominal rash
   - ID recs
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - CT shows e/o new pseudocyst, may contribute to abdominal distention
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - trend Hct
   .
   # abdominal rash
 Continues to spread.  Thought to be drug-induced,
   with the most likely suspect being abx.  Both vancomycin and meropenem
   have been d/ced since development of rash.
   - continue to monitor
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   Now with worsening abdominal distention, although this could be from
   massive fluid overload.
   - cont vanc enemas + IV flagyl and cont for until has completed other
   antibiotics then for an additional 14d
   - transduce bladder pressure serially
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - amiodarone redosed to gtt given inability to administer PO meds;
   after 1 week will need to redose
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.
   .

   MICU Attending Addendum:
   On this day I examined the patient and was present for the key portions
   of the services provided.  I have reviewed Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 12690**]
s note above
   and agree with his findings and plan of care.  Mr [**Known lastname 12624**] is a
   previously healthy elderly man with severe pancreatitis, psedocysts,
   pseudoanerysm, s/p PEA arrest with CPR for 25min, renal failure, resp
   failure, hypotension on pressors, severe ongoing leukocytosis, and
   obtundation despite our stopping sedatives.
   His obtundation is likely multifactorial. He did respond to commands
   shortly after being resuscitated, so I doubt anoxic encephalopathy
   explains it all. But this CNS insult, plus his age and renal failure
   and the SIRS state from pancreatitis may well be enough to keep him
   obtunded. His obtundation is contributing to his being on the vent
   still, as is his tense abdomen and acidosis and fluid overload.  His
   renal failure is likely from both his CP Arrest and pancreatitis.
   His prognosis is obviously not good, given the co-morbidities of great
   severity.  Goals of care are to be addressed by his neice who is his
   health care proxy, and another relative who is a physician. [**Name10 (NameIs) **] the
   desire is to continue
aggressive
 care, then he will need CNS imaging
   in addition to the EEG the results of which are pending. He will also
   need consideration of CVHD by renal in an effort to get off fluid,
   correct hyponatremia, and improve mental status.  His pseudocysts are
   very large and he remains on broad spectrum antibiotics. Surgery
   following and we
ll discuss with them if any intervention is in order,
   which I doubt.
   If, however, goals of care are desired by family to be directed toward
   comfort, we are prepared to move in that direction as well.
   50min spent in the care of this complex and critically ill patient.
   [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 712**], MD

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH who was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has been diagnosed with severe pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocysts, intra-abdominal fluid collections, and a gastro-duodenal artery pseudoaneurysm that required interventional radiology-guided embolization. The patient also has acute renal failure, unresponsiveness after a pulseless event, aspiration pneumonia, Clostridium difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and is being treated with multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem, which have been discontinued due to the development of an abdominal rash. The patient's family has been informed about his condition and the goals of care, and they are amenable to continuing aggressive treatment.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are rising, indicating worsening renal function. He is already on furosemide (Lasix) but continues to have worsening hyponatremia. The plan is to monitor electrolytes and consider continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) if necessary.

- He has hyperglycemia, possibly secondary to pancreatic insufficiency or new-onset diabetes mellitus.
- Imaging reveals hepatic cirrhosis, but hepatology team felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.
- The patient's family contact is his niece, who can be reached at [**NI 12548**] [**NI 12549**].

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH who was transferred from another hospital for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections, which are thought to be related to his pseudocyst. His course has been complicated by GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring interventional radiology (IR) guided embolization. He also has acute renal failure, unresponsiveness following a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, aspiration pneumonia, pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocysts, intra-abdominal fluid collections, abdominal rash, Clostridium difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are rising, indicating worsening renal function. He has a history of acute renal failure during his admission at the other hospital, and there is a potential for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to the recent IR procedure. The patient's urine osmolality is consistent with an intrarenal process, and he has hyponatremia. Monitoring of electrolytes and trends in creatinine is recommended.

2. Unresponsiveness: The patient remains unresponsive after discontinuation of midazolam for sedation. Differential diagnoses include sedation (impaired renal clearance), uremia, structural defect

Summary: The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH, who was transferred from an outside hospital for evaluation of pancreatitis. His course has been complicated by GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring interventional radiology (IR) guided embolization. The patient experienced an episode of pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, after which he remained unresponsive. He also has acute renal failure, aspiration pneumonia, multiple abdominal fluid collections, and Clostridium difficile infection. Additionally, the patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis. He is currently intubated for airway protection and on mechanical ventilation. The patient's family has been informed of his condition and consented to continue aggressive care.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for evaluation of acute pancreatitis. The patient has several medical complications, including acute renal failure, unresponsiveness after a pulseless event, pancreatitis with pancreatic pseudocysts and intra-abdominal fluid collections, Clostridium difficile infection, atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have been rising, indicating worsening renal function. There is a concern for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to the pulseless event and potential nephrotoxic medications. The plan is to monitor electrolytes and trend creatinine levels, avoid nephrotoxic medications, and consider continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) if necessary.

2. Unresponsiveness: The patient remains unresponsive after discontinuation of midazolam for sedation. Differential diagnoses include sedation (impaired renal clearance), uremia, structural defect (i.e., stroke), seizure, and metabolic (i.e., hyponatremia). Further evaluation is needed, including follow-up EEG results to rule out epileptiform activity.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH, who was transferred from an OSH for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has multiple severe medical problems including pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation, respiratory failure, renal failure, cardiac issues, fevers, severe leukocytosis, Clostridium difficile infection, hypotension, and obtundation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have been increasing, indicating worsening renal function. This could potentially progress to acute renal failure if not managed appropriately.
2. Unresponsiveness: The patient remains unresponsive after a pulseless event, which could be due to various causes such as sedation (impaired renal clearance), uremia, structural defect (i.e., stroke), seizure, or metabolic (i.e., hyponatremia).
3. Pancreatitis and Pancreatic Pseudocysts: The patient has a history of pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation, which can lead to complications like hemorrhage, infection, and obstruction.
4. Intra-abdominal Fluid Collections: The patient has multiple large abdominal fluid collections, which can cause abdominal distention and increase the risk of infection.
5. Clostridium difficile Infection: The patient has been diagnosed with C. difficile infection, which can worsen if not treated promptly.
6. Hepatic Cirrhosis: Imaging studies revealed hepatic cirrhosis

He has several comorbidities including atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, hepatic cirrhosis (disputed diagnosis), and renal failure. The patient underwent an ERCP, which revealed a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections. He also had a GDA pseudoaneurysm that was embolized. The patient developed an abdominal rash thought to be drug-induced, and he had an episode of unresponsiveness after a PEA arrest. He is currently on multiple antibiotics, including Aztreonam and Cipro, and is also receiving TPN.

Potential Medical Complications:

The patient's urine electrolytes suggest an intrarenal process.
2. Unresponsiveness: The patient experienced an episode of unresponsiveness following a PEA arrest. It is unclear what caused the arrest, but possible causes include sedation (impaired renal clearance), uremia, structural defect (stroke), seizure, or metabolic disturbance (hyponatremia).

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH, who was admitted for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR-guided embolization. The patient has been unresponsive since a PEA arrest, with unclear precipitant. No hypoglycemia or electrolyte imbalances were noted at the time of the event. The differential diagnosis includes sedation, uremia, structural defect (i.e., stroke), seizure, and metabolic causes (i.e., hyponatremia). The patient has been on multiple antibiotics due to suspected infections, including C. difficile, which was initially positive but improved with Flagyl. He also has atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis, although the latter two diagnoses are not confirmed. The patient's family has been informed and is amenable to CRRT.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are rising, indicating worsening renal function. He has been given Lasix to improve urine output, but his creatinine continues to rise. Hyponatremia is also worsening. The patient's history of pulseless time during PEA arrest raises the possibility of ATN. Monitoring of electrolytes

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of BPH who was admitted for evaluation of pancreatitis. The patient's course has been complicated by several medical conditions and complications. 

1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have been rising, indicating worsening renal function. There is concern for acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to the pulseless event. The patient's urine output (UOP) improved with the administration of Lasix, but his creatinine continued to rise. He is experiencing worsening hyponatremia as well. The plan is to monitor electrolytes and trend creatinine, avoid nephrotoxic medications, and consider continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) given the family's amenability.

2. Unresponsiveness post Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA) arrest: The patient remains unresponsive after discontinuation of midazolam for sedation. Differential diagnoses include sedation (impaired renal clearance), uremia, structural defect (i.e., stroke), seizure, and metabolic (i.e., hyponatremia). Further evaluation is needed, including follow-up EEG results to rule out epileptiform activity, and reassessment of mental status following withdrawal of midazolam.
